title: Why did Bank of America give me a 1099A if they sold my 2nd mortgage to a debt collection agency anyway? Can they do both?
question: My house in California foreclosed last year. Now a debt collecting agency is collecting on my 2nd mortgage (refinanced) which they bought from Bank of America. Can Bank of America have it both ways by giving me a 1099A AND also sell my debt to a collecting agency?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Foreclosure,Tax return,Mortgage debt,Tax law
answers: If this was your primary residence, the 1099a income may not be taxable. Look at form 982 and instructions. If you took cash out on a refinance, that amount may be taxable. This is something you need a tax adviser on. To answer your direct question, yes they can do that.

Yes, they could do both.

Form 1099-A is Acquisition or Abandonment of Secured Property. Form 1099-C is Cancellation of Debt.

Form 1099-A is needed to report the foreclosure on your tax return. A foreclosure is treated as the sale of property, and you will need it to calculate your gain or loss on the property.

Form 1099-C is used if the lender both foreclosed on the property and canceled any mortgage debt. Here, your bank did not cancel the mortgage debt on the 2nd; the bank merely sold the debt to a collection agency.

On the Form 1099-A, check to see whether box 5 is checked. If yes, this means you had "recourse" debt and the foreclosure sale does not satisfy the debt. You will need to report the sale on schedule D of your Form 1040 with the date sold and the sales price (lesser of box 2 or 4 on the 1099-A). If box 5 of Form 1099-A was not checked, you have "non-recourse" debt, which means the foreclosure satisfies the bank's debt. Enter the information on Schedule D of your Form 1040 with the date sold and the sales price (box 2 on Form 1099-A).

For more information on debt forgiveness, 1099-A, and 1099-C, see:

http://www.irs.gov/instructions/i1099ac/ar02.html

http://www.irs.gov/newsroom/article/0,,id=174034,00.html

There is also an IRS Publication 4681:

http://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p4681.pdf
